creator: Tiemen_Goossens
title: The Automatic Pill Dispenser
materials_required: Mdf: 4 mm thickness for the inner case
Mdf: 3 and 6 mm thickness for the outer case
Resistors: 1 x 270 ohm, 1 x 330 ohm, 1 x 470 ohm, 5 x 10k ohm
3D printed parts: upper tube, cylinder, axis, lower tube, slide
description: The automatic pill dispenser is a mechatronic system designed to remind users to take their pills and dispense them. It aims to assist absent-minded elderly individuals and caregivers by automating pill dispensing in a user-friendly manner.
steps: Cut the inner case using 4mm MDF into 5 plates that fit together like a puzzle. A sixth plate can be used as a lid.

Construct the dispensing mechanism by creating a storage compartment with a slanted bottom, an upper tube, a cylinder with a hole, and a lower tube with a sensor. 3D print the tubes, cylinder, axis and slide.
Assemble the storage compartment plates using laser-cut plates with puzzle-like interlocking features.
Connect the upper tube to one side of the inner box using a plate attached to it.
Connect the cylinder to the servo motor on one side and the other side of the box on the other side using the bearings.
Fabricate the lower tube and sensor compartment, integrating an IR emitter and IR detector to confirm pill dispensing.
Mount the 3D printed tube to the inner case using bolts.
Use a servomotor to rotate the cylinder, driven by the Arduino Uno microcontroller.
Use a transistor to drive a small DC motor with an unbalance for vibration as a reminder, including a diode to prevent backflow current.
Connect an infrared emitter and detector to the Arduino Uno to confirm pill passage.
Laser cut the outer case using 3mm and 6mm medium density fiberboard, ensuring a tight fit.
Connect external electronics, including an LCD, buzzer, LED, and buttons, to function as an alarm clock and user interface.
Assemble all components, using glue, tape, and screws for stability.
Upload the Arduino code to control the system.
Be mindful of the potential for pill contamination and the complexity of cleaning the machine between different medications.
